cells.data: Basically, we can use Huybrecht's proof of 4.4.6 in Complex Geometry (see below) with **compatible families of admissible** simplicial connections (see [Simplicial connections and other conventions](quiver-note-url/C3C5014A-E7C2-4469-8B4C-9FDC60035242)), but the line bundle case works nicely by hand, as follows.
**Motto.** _We transgress $c_k$ of a rank-$r$ bundle to $\H^{2k-1}(W_{n,n-k+1};\mathbb{Z})$; see [Stiefel manifolds](quiver-note-url/312D14CA-F4D9-4F38-A5EB-1D87A0EB8842)._

#### Transition maps POV

Pull back our line bundle $E$ to the space of $1$-frames in $\mathbb{C}$, which is just $\mathrm{GL}_1(\mathbb{C})$. The local sections $s_\alpha\colon x\mapsto(x,\sigma_\alpha(x))$ of $E$ pull back to
\begin{align*}
    \pi_* s_\alpha\colon U_\alpha\times\mathrm{GL}_1&\to(U_\alpha\times\mathrm{GL}_1)\times\mathbb{C}^\times\\
    (x,m)&\mapsto((x,m),\sigma_\alpha(x))
\end{align*}
(**N.B.** $\pi$ here is the map from the associated bundle of $1$-frames to $X$ — should really change the notation to $p$ or something less misleading...)
but we also have the global section
\begin{align*}
    s\colon U_\alpha\times\mathrm{GL}_1&\to(U_\alpha\times\mathrm{GL}_1)\times\mathbb{C}^\times\\
    (x,m)&\mapsto((x,m),m).
\end{align*}

Since $s_\beta=g_{\alpha\beta}s_\alpha$ we see that $$\pi^*g_{\alpha\beta} = \frac{\pi^*s_\beta}{\pi^*s_\alpha} = \frac{(\pi^*s_\beta)/s}{(\pi^*s_\alpha)/s}$$ where we note that $\pi^*s_\alpha$ is just a section, but $(\pi^*s_\alpha)/s$ is a true function.

Then $\mathrm{at}_E = g_{\alpha\beta}^{-1}\mathrm{d}g_{\alpha\beta}\in\check{\mathcal{C}}^1(\Omega^1)$ is such that $\pi^*\mathrm{at}_E = \check{\delta}\mathrm{dlog}(\pi^*s_\alpha/s)$. This is our transgression.

Further, we can recover the generator of homology on the fibre as follows. The function $\pi^*s_\alpha/s$ acts as $(x,m)\mapsto((x,m),1/m)$ (since we can assume that $\sigma_\alpha(x)=1$ for **some** $\alpha$) and so 
\begin{align*}
    \mathrm{dlog}(\pi^*s_\alpha/s) &= \mathrm{dlog}(1/z)\\
    &= \frac{\mathrm{d}(1/z)}{(1/z)}\\
    &= -\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{z}\\
    &= \pm\frac{\mathrm{d}(re^{i\theta})}{re^{i\theta}}\\
    &= \frac{1}{r}\mathrm{d}r+i\mathrm{d}\theta.
\end{align*}

#### Connections POV

Since $\pi^*E$ is trivial we have a global connection $\nabla$. Then $$\pi^*(\nabla_\beta-\nabla_\alpha) = (\pi^*\nabla_\beta-\nabla)-(\pi^*\nabla_\alpha-\nabla) =: \vartheta_\beta-\vartheta_\alpha = \check{\delta}\vartheta_\alpha$$ for some Čech-1-cochain $\vartheta_\alpha$ of a 1-form, since the difference of two connections is a 1-form.

Now, the $s_\alpha$ are taken to be $\nabla_\alpha$-flat, and $s$ is (trivially) $\nabla$-flat, whence, assuming (wlog) that $\sigma_\alpha(x)=1$, $$s_\alpha\colon(x,m)\mapsto\big((x,m),1\big)=\big((x,m),z\cdot 1/z\big) = \frac{1}{z}s.$$
Then, by Leibnitz and flatness,
\begin{align*}
    \vartheta_\alpha s_\alpha &= -\nabla s_\alpha\\
    &= -\nabla\left(\frac{1}{z}s\right)\\
    &= -\frac{1}{z}\nabla(s) - s\otimes\mathrm{d}(1/z)\\
    &= s\mathrm{d}(1/z)\\
    &= \frac{-z\mathrm{d}z}{z^2}\\
    &= -\frac{\mathrm{d}z}{z}.
\end{align*}

#### Simplicial proof

We can adapt the proof in Huybrecht's if we can show the following five statements are true.

1. _The difference of two simplicial connections is an admissible endomorphism-valued simplicial 1-form._
2. _$K(\nabla_\bullet+A_\bullet) = K(\nabla_\bullet)+A_\bullet\wedge A_\bullet+\nabla_\bullet(A_\bullet)$._
3. $\tilde{P}(K(\nabla_\bullet+A_\bullet)) = \tilde{P}(K(\nabla_\bullet))+ktP(K(\nabla_\bullet),\ldots,K(\nabla_\bullet),\nabla_\bullet(A_\bullet))+\mathcal{O}(t^2)$
4. $\nabla_\bullet(K(\nabla_\bullet))$ _(the Bianchi identity)._
5. $\mathrm{d}P(\gamma_\bullet^1,\ldots,\gamma_\bullet^k)=\sum_{j=1}^k(-1)^{\text{sign}}P(\gamma_\bullet^1,\ldots,\nabla_\bullet(\gamma_\bullet^j),\ldots,\gamma_\bullet^k)$.

Let's prove them.

1. This is true if we have a **compatible family of admissible simplicial connections**.
2. This works level-by-level, and that our simplicial connection is admissible ensures that all the forms are admissible endomorphism-valued simplicial forms.
3. As above.
4. As above.
5. As above, as well as the fact that $\tilde{P}$ acts on the form parts by wedging, and the wedge of two simplicial forms is again simplicial.
